item.title: Hall of fame
item.description:
List of completed projects that I’m proud of.

JRotorMap

A simple hamradio app written in Java.

Potential spoon

Such a wonderful fractal generator in MIPS assembly. Nice pictures included!

Animacja

An core 3.3 OpenGL project for another class - without using any high-level libraries(even without model-loading!) so it was a challenging one. The most helpful material that I found was LearnOpenGL tutorial which helped me a lot.(Shaders are maybe a bit similar, but shh!) I wish I had more time, so I might implement a flashlight or something like that.

Kalman

Project for ZPR(Really enjoyable class!) - completed in one semester. Multi-language(connecting C++ and Python were an unforgettable experience) app which uses an Kalman filter to predict movement from sensors. While working on it, I discovered that Slack + Jenkins + Git can make a game-changer team, making developing multi-platform program and working in team a lot easier.

item.title: Windows 7 and time
item.description:
Some time ago I encountered an unordinary problem: I had to set a specific time in Windows 7 in order to run certain app. Unfortunately, Windows weren’t happy enough to allow me to do so, constantly changing time.

How I fixed it?

@echo off
:loop
date 12-07-27
time 14:24:00
goto loop

Don’t do it.

And what was the reason? Windows 7 in this particular situation didn’t allow me to change time - it was still changing, no matter what I had done - so, such a dirty trick was a way to do what I want to do.

item.title: tcsd and rngd together
item.description:
There’s a tricky way to don’t choose between rngd or SSH keys wired with your computer because it is possible to use it in one time, despite the fact that they both want exclusive access to TPM.

To do that, you should create a file 

/etc/modules-load.d/tpm-rng.conf
with one line: 
tpm-rng
And restart or modprobe that module. When you can see a /dev/hwrng device, then it’s necessary to point a rngd daemon to it(f.e. in /etc/modules-load.d/tpm-rng.conf on Archlinux): 
RNGD_OPTS="-r /dev/hwrng"

And that’s all. Both services are running on my laptop without any problem.

item.title: hello go
item.description: New start with another static generator - as you can see, it’s hugo this time.
